raw_text:
Athens memories soar above lows
 
 Well, it's goodbye to another Olympic year and as usual there were plenty of highs and lows in Athens.
 
 Obviously, there's no getting away from the differing fortunes of Kelly Holmes and Paula Radcliffe. But I want to remind you of a few more events that made 2004 another year to remember - or forget - for athletics. 
 
  
 
 One of my favourite Olympic moments was Kelly's success in the 800m.
 
 Winning that race was the key to her success because if she won that then the 1500m would be a bit of a formality. Kelly had been full of "should I, shouldn't I?" thoughts about going for the double in Athens. I thought why wouldn't you do the 800m, it's your best event? It was such good fun to commentate on her 1500m and it was nice to be able to be part of her Athens story. 
 
  
 
 The victory for the British men's 4x100m relay team was a bit of a surprise but a great climax to the Games. I think the four of them - Jason Gardener, Darren Campbell, Marlon Devonish and Mark Lewis-Francis - knew deep down that it was their best chance of a medal. The lads had run poorly in the individual sprints so maybe they did lift their game when they knew something was really at stake. 
 
  
 
 Hicham El Guerrouj's Olympic double is a much bigger achievement than Kelly's on a global scale.
 
 He was the first man since for 80 years to win both the 1500m and 5,000m titles. As soon as he had added the 5,000m crown and I had finished commentating, I jumped up, ran down the stairs, pushed everyone out the way and just gave him a big hug. He is one of the few African runners who has embraced the tradition of the mile and he loves to hear all the Roger Bannister stories. Hicham is someone I enjoy having a bit of time with, even though my French and his English are not very good. 
 
  
 
 What happened to Paula in Athens this year is the obvious low on a personal level and for the expectations of the nation as well. There were a set of circumstances around Athens that conspired to produce a very dramatic ending which I think has been greatly misunderstood. Dropping out of the marathon was the right thing to do but starting in the 10,000m five days later was not wise. That was her heart and not her head reacting. Paula had a lot of little things going wrong in her preparation and on the day.
 
 Things like niggling injuries, not being able to do all her running sessions and feeling the pressure of the race looming ahead of her. I think she came to the start line in Athens physically and emotionally drained. And if even the smallest thing doesn't feel right when you are preparing to race a marathon, 10 miles down the road it will hit you like a brick wall. The positive thing to take from Paula's Olympics it that she will have learned a lot from it and so will a lot of people - including me. 
 
  
 
 Purely as a race, Paula's victory in the New York Marathon has to go down as one of the most thrilling. It was so nip-and-tuck between her and Kenya's Susan Chepkemei and you don't usually get that kind of excitement in marathons. It was also a real delight for all athletics fans because, to use one of my favourite words, Paula showed real "bouncebackability". And it was a bit of a rarity for me too because I genuinely did not have an inkling how the race was going to pan out. 
 
  
 
 Kelly and the 4x100m boys' victories papered over the cracks in the general performance of the British team. We should be concerned that we're not producing enough people who are capable of reaching finals at senior level.
 
 The only individual men's finalist on the track was Michael East in the 1500m. I am beginning to look down and wonder where are the new breed? And that's where things begin to look even gloomier for British athletics as we did not win any medals at the world junior championships in Italy. Dani Barnes came fourth in the 1500m and she was the highest finisher for Team GB. The thing is if we don't have athletes getting into the finals at junior level then it really doesn't look good for the Beijing Olympics and beyond. 
 
  
 
 I tell you what I really enjoyed this year, Benita Johnson winning the world cross country championships back in March. In the absence of Paula, we tend to think of the event as something of an African preserve. So to have an Australian come up and deliver such a surprise was something special. 
 
  
 
 To be honest, I'm getting bored with all the drug scandals, especially Balco. I just wish the whole thing would come to a head so we can move on.
 
 Having said that, I'm always pleased when drugs cheats are caught because it shows the sport is standing up to it and not turning a blind eye anymore. And one of the positive things to come out of Balco is people are starting to blow the whistle. We need more people to come forward and help the authorities kick out the cheats. As regards the case against Greek sprinters Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou, well suspicions have been hanging over Kenteris for a while. The bottom line is we cannot keep letting drugs damage the sport because if we do then it stops everyone enjoying it.
llama3.2:1b:
Athens memories soar above lows as Olympic year brings highs and lows in athletics. 

Kelly Holmes' 800m victory was key to success, as winning made her double a formality. The British men's 4x100m relay team won despite poorly run individual sprints.

Hicham El Guerrouj dominated the 1500m and 5,000m titles, with both victories being historic on a global scale.

Paula Radcliffe's Olympic performance was marred by injuries and pressure. However, she showed bouncebackability in her New York Marathon victory over Susan Chepkemei.

The British team lacked medalists at the world junior championships, and the lack of progress from athletes to reach finals at senior level is a concern.

Athletics needs more talented individuals reaching the finals, particularly at the junior level.
llama3.2:3b: Kelly Holmes won 800m and 1500m golds; British men's 4x100m relay team won a surprise medal; Hicham El Guerrouj became the first African to win Olympic 1500m and 5000m titles; Paula Radcliffe dropped out of the marathon due to injuries, then came back to lose in the New York Marathon; Britain underperformed at the Olympics and junior championships.
gemma2:2b: Kelly Holmes won the 800m at the 2004 Olympics, which was key to her winning the 1500m. Hicham El Guerrouj won both the 1500m and 5,000m races, making him a globally significant achievement. Paula Radcliffe's Olympic journey ended prematurely due to personal circumstances, but she later had a successful marathon in New York. The British athletics team underperformed in general at the Olympics. Concerns regarding future success for athletes are raised as there were no medalists from Britain at the junior world championships. Benita Johnson won the World Cross Country Championships in a surprise victory. Drug scandals continue to plague the sport, prompting calls for greater transparency and accountability.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
Key ideas:

- Athens Olympics: A year filled with highs and lows, with some memorable moments like Kelly Holmes' 800m victory.
- Paula Radcliffe: An Olympic champion who surprised many at the 2004 Athens Games by finishing first in the marathon, despite her age.
- British Athletes: A year marked by an athlete from Australia winning a race that would have been considered impossible for someone of her size. The surprise victory was given a big hug and praised as "one of the most thrilling."
- Cross Country Championships: Australian runner Benita Johnson won the World Cross Country Championships, showing national pride.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Athens' highs include Kelly Holmes winning the 800m and Britain's 4x100 relay team reaching a medal climax. Paula Radcliffe's Olympic double of 5,000m and marathon, although disappointing, is celebrated. The British team struggles with poor results, while Johnson wins cross country championships despite a doping scandal. Paula's race in New York is considered thrilling but not without its critics. Balco scandals continue to attract attention.
qwen2.5:3b: Athens memories are mixed as another Olympic year comes to an end, featuring standout moments like Kelly Holmes' 800m victory and Hicham El Guerrouj's double gold. However, Paula Rad her marathon withdrawal is seen as a disappointment, highlighting concerns about British athletes’ readiness for future Olympics. Benita Johnson’s world cross country win adds another silver lining to the year. Despite controversies surrounding drug use scandals like BALCO, there is a growing desire to address doping issues and ensure fair play in athletics.
opencoder:1.5b:
Athens Memories Soar Above Lows

Well, it's goodbye to another Olympic year and as usual there were plenty of highs and lows in Athens. Obviously, there's no getting away from the differing fortunes of Kelly Holmes and Paula Radcliffe. But I want to remind you of a few more events that made 2004 another year to remember - or forget - for athletics. 

One of my favourite Olympic moments was Kelly's success in the 800m. The winning race was the key to her success because if she won that then the 15,000m would be a bit of a formality. Kelly had been full of "should I, shouldn't I?" thoughts about going for the double in Athens. I thought why wouldn't you do the 800m, it's your best event? It was such good fun to commentate on her 15,000m and it was nice to be able to be part of her Athens story. 

The victory for the British men's 4x100m relay team was a bit of a surprise but a great climax to the Games. I think the four of them - Jason Gardener, Darren Campbell, Marlon Devonish and Mark Lewis-Francis - knew deep down that it was their best chance of a medal. The lads had run poorly in the individual sprints so maybe they did lift their game when they knew something was really at stake. 

Purely as a race, Paula's victory in the New York Marathon has to go down as one of the most thrilling. It was so nip-and-tuck between her and Kenya's Susan Chepkemei and you don't usually get that kind of excitement in marathons. It was also a real delight for all athletics fans because, to use one of my favourite words, Paula showed real "bouncebackability". And it was a bit of a rarity for me too because I genuinely did not have an inkling how the race was going to pan out. 

Kelly and the 4x100m boys' victories papered over the cracks in the general performance of the British team. We should be concerned that we're not producing enough people who are capable of reaching finals at senior level.

The only individual men's finalist on the track was Michael East in the 15,000m. I am beginning to look down and wonder where are the new breed? And that's where things begin to look even gloomier for British athletics as we did not win any medals at the world junior championships in Italy. Dani Barnes came fourth in the 15,000m and she was the highest finisher for Team GB. The thing is if we don't have athletes getting into the finals at junior level then it really doesn't look good for the Beijing Olympics and beyond. 

I tell you what I really enjoyed this year, Benita Johnson winning the world cross country championships back in March. In the absence of Paula, we tend to think of the event as something of an African preserve. So to have an Australian come up and deliver such a surprise was something special. 

As regards the case against Greek sprinters Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou, well suspicions have been hanging over Kenteris for a while. The bottom line is we cannot keep letting drugs damage the sport because if we do then it stops everyone enjoying it. As about the case against Greek sprinters, the sport is still in its infancy, and it's hard to imagine that they'd be able to compete with any other athlete without committing a few mistakes.
smollm:1.7b: I think you meant to say "balco" instead of "Balco". I'm not sure what you mean by "bored with all the drug scandals", but I can try to help clarify that for you!

Atens memories soar above lows

They mention a few notable events such as Kelly Holmes' 800m victory and Paula Radcliffe's marathon success, as well as the New York Marathon triumph of Purely's Kenyan rival Susan Chepkemei. tinydolphin:1.1b:
Athens was an exhilarating Games filled with memorable moments, both personal and international. As the silver-haired commentator who has seen countless athletes perform at their best, I have witnessed some truly remarkable athletic feats. It is a testament to the sport's continued growth in terms of athletes, coaches, support staff, sponsors and fans. 

What stood out most about this year was the overwhelming success of the British women's team in both sprint events. Paula Radcliffe's victory at the New York Marathon marked a pivotal moment for athletics. It not only demonstrated her talent, but it also showcased the potential of future generations to break records and make their mark on the international stage.

In the 1500m, Olympic gold medallist Kelly Holmes achieved a remarkable personal best by defeating a field that included world record-holder Florence Griffith-Joakim and current world leader Mariyuhu Ramasegran. Holmes' win signified not just a personal achievement but also a historic moment for British athletics, as it marked the first time a British woman had won an Olympic 1500m event since 1948.

The triumph of the British men's 4x100m relay team at Athens was another memorable moment in the sport. Hicham El Guerrouj, along with Marlon Devonish and Mark Lewis-Francis, demonstrated that even a single athlete can have an impact on the outcome of a race. Their success was fueled by their collective determination to perform at their best, regardless of the circumstances surrounding them.

Another standout performance was Paula Radcliffe's victory in the 800m. Although her victory may not have been her best event, it served as a reminder that even the greatest athletes can be overshadowed by otherworldly performances. As someone who has seen many remarkable athletic achievements, I believe it is important for athletics to remember its roots and continue to celebrate the great moments of our past while striving towards greater heights in the future.
phi:2.7b: The text talks about the highs and lows of the 2004 Olympics. It mentions two successful athletes - Kelly Holmes in the 800m and Hicham El Guerrouj's double win in both 1500m and 5000m races. The British men's 4x100m relay team also won a gold medal, which was unexpected but celebrated. However, there were some disappointments, such as Paula Radcliffe withdrawing from the marathon race and Brits failing to make finals at other events. The text expresses concern about Britain's ability to produce top-performing athletes. It highlights the achievements of Benita Johnson in the world cross country championships and hopes that the drug scandals like Balco will be resolved soon.
orca-mini:3b:
Well, that's another Olympic year in the books! It was definitely a memorable one for athletics with plenty of highs and lows, including Kelly Holmes and Paula Radcliffe's victories and Hicham El Guerrouj's double gold. The British men's 4x100m relay team had a surprise victory, while the men's 1500m race was a bit of a dud. However, the women's 800m and mile races were great to watch. The marathoners didn't have it all their way either, with Paula dropping out just before the finish line.

There were some encouraging developments as well, such as Dani Barnes' performance in the 1500m at the world junior championships. And as you mentioned, there was a surprise winner in the cross country race for the men - Benita Johnson from Australia. It was great to see her win.

Overall, it was a year with a lot of ups and downs, but I'm glad we got to witness some truly thrilling athletic performances.
hermes3:3b: Athens Olympics highlights: Kelly Holmes' 800m win, British men's 4x100m relay victory, Hicham El Guerrouj's Olympic double; Paula Radcliffe's personal low (marathon drop-out), positive from NY Marathon; concern over lack of senior-level athletes.
stablelm-zephyr:3b: The text discusses various aspects of the Athens Olympic Games in 2004, highlighting key moments and performances in athletics. It emphasizes Kelly Holmes' success in the 800m race, the British men's 4x100m relay team's victory, Hicham El Guerrouj's achievement in winning both the 1500m and 5000m titles, Paula Radcliffe's dramatic ending to her marathon race, and the importance of producing capable athletes for future competitions. The author also expresses their enjoyment of Benita Johnson's win at the world cross country championships. Additionally, they comment on the increasing focus on drug scandals in sports and the need for more whistleblowers to help expose cheats.
stablelm2:1.6b: Athens 2004 witnessed both highs (Kelly Holmes' Olympic double) and lows (Paula Radcliffe's withdrawal). Highlights included Kelly's victory in the marathon, Jason Gardener & Marlon Devonish's successful 4x400m relay, and Hicham El Guerrouj's historic win in the 5,000m and 10,0 Sprints. The most dramatic event was Paula Radcliffe's sudden withdrawal from the marathon due to personal circumstances. In contrast, her New York Marathon victory showcased exceptional resilience for athletics fans. Kelly's victories and Hicham's achievements overshadowed a concerning lack of medal production by the British team during and after the Games. This issue highlights potential challenges facing British athletics in future events. Lastly, there was excitement surrounding Benita Johnson's successful cross-country championship win, although drug scandals have tainted discussions. Overall, 2004 Olympic memories soared above such lows, leaving us hoping for improved performance from future athletes and reduced involvement of cheats in the sport.
granite3.1-dense:2b:
In 2004 Athens Olympics, several notable events stand out amidst the highs and lows:

1. Kelly Holmes' success in the 800m was pivotal for her double win in the 1500m. Commentating on her victory and the subsequent relay team performance were highlights.
2. The British men's 4x100m relay team secured a surprising but thrilling gold medal, demonstrating they had their best chance to medal in Athens.
3. Hicham El Guerrouj achieved an Olympic double by winning both the 1500m and 5,000m, marking a significant global achievement as the first man to do so since 1924.
4. Paula Radcliffe's withdrawal from the marathon after 30km due to physical and emotional exhaustion, injuries, and pressure was a major low for her personal career and national expectations.
5. Despite her early retirement from the marathon, Paula's victory in the New York Marathon five days later showcased her resilience and "bouncebackability," offering a positive takeaway from her Olympic experience.
6. Kelly Holmes' and the British men's 4x100m relay team successes helped mask concerns about the general performance of the British athletics team, which has been criticized for not producing enough finalists at senior level.
7. Michael East's individual finalist spot in the 1500m and Dani Barnes' fourth-place finish were minor bright spots but underscored deeper concerns about Britain's lack of junior athletes reaching finals, which could negatively impact future Olympic performances.
8. Benita Johnson's world cross country championship win as an Austrican was a delightful surprise, highlighting the global appeal of the event beyond its perceived African focus.
9. The author expressed frustration with ongoing drug scandals, particularly Balco, but welcomed the catching and prosecution of cheats, emphasizing the sport's commitment to cleanliness.
10. The lingering suspicions around Greek sprinters Kostas Kenteris and Katerina Thanou due to Balco further highlighted the need for athletes to come forward and expose drug-related wrongdoing.

Kelly Holmes' victory in the 800m set the stage for her 1500m win, while the British men's 4x100m relay team surprised with gold. Hicham El Guerrouj's historic 1500m and 5,000m double was a major global achievement. Paula Radcliffe's struggles in Athens were a disappointment, but her thrilling New York Marathon win showcased resilience. Concerns remain over British athletics' future, with a lack of emerging talent. Benita Johnson's cross-country win was a highlight, and drug scandals, particularly Balco, continue to plague the sport, though whistleblowing offers hope for cleaner competition.
